user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calc_userdigest:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
calc_userdigest (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                 const char *username, const size_t username_len,
                 const char *realm, const size_t realm_len,
                 const char *password,
                 uint8_t *ha1_bin)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
  digest_update (da, username, username_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update (da, realm, realm_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update_str (da, password);
  digest_calc_hash (da, ha1_bin);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function calc_userdigest:
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_update (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
               const void *data,
               size_t length)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
    MHD_MD5_update (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
    MHD_SHA256_update (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
    MHD_SHA512_256_update (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx,
                           (const uint8_t *) data, length);
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0);   /* May not happen */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->hashing = true;
#endif
}
...
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_update_with_colon (struct DigestAlgorithm *da)
{
  static const uint8_t colon = (uint8_t) ':';
  digest_update (da, &colon, 1);
}
...
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_update_str (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                   const char *str)
{
  const size_t str_len = strlen (str);
  digest_update (da, (const uint8_t *) str, str_len);
}
...
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_calc_hash (struct DigestAlgorithm *da, uint8_t *digest)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_MD5_finish (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_finish_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    MHD_SHA256_finish (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_finish_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    MHD_SHA512_256_finish (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx, digest);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0);   /* Should not happen */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Reasoning: 

- calc_userdigest: the function only calls other helpers and does not assign to any of its parameters (da, username, username_len, realm, realm_len, password, ha1_bin). There are no statements like da = ..., username = ..., or ha1_bin = .... All uses are either passing the pointers on or dereferencing them via called functions.

- digest_update: the function dereferences da (e.g., da->ctx, da->hashing) and calls hash update functions. It does not assign to the pointer parameter da itself. Modifications to members of *da (da->hashing = true under _DEBUG) are allowed by Rule 17.8 (the pointee may be modified).

- digest_update_with_colon: builds a local static const colon and calls digest_update(da, &colon, 1). It does not modify the pointer parameter da or the caller-provided pointer.

- digest_update_str: computes strlen(str) and calls digest_update. It does not reassign the pointer parameter str; reading via strlen is allowed.

- digest_calc_hash: calls finishing functions that write to the memory pointed to by the digest parameter (allowed — the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). The function modifies members of *da (e.g., da->ready_for_hashing, da->hashing under _DEBUG) but does not reassign the pointer parameter da or the pointer parameter digest.

- mhd_assert is defined as ((void)0), so assertions do not perform any pointer assignments.

Therefore, no evidence of pointer-parameter reassignment exists in the provided code; all pointer modifications are to the pointee objects (which is permitted by Rule 17.8).
